title: What happens in enzyme catalyzed reactions when the rate of dissociation of ES to products is higher than the rate of ES dissociation back to substrate and enzyme? - Quora

response.answer_text: In that situation E + S → ES → E + P [math]k_{cat}/K_{m} = k_{1}[/math] The rate of the reaction equals the rate of association of the enzyme and substrate. The magnitude of the second order rate constant is about [math]10^{8}s^{-1}M^{-1}[/math], indicating a diffusion controlled reaction. Several enzymes do operate close to the diffusion controlled limit. The list I have in front of me is acetylcholinesterase, carbonic anhydrase, catalase, crotonase, fumarase, triosephosphate isomerase, beta-lactamase, and superoxide dismutase.* *Table 4.5 in Ferscht, Alan “Structure and Mechanism in Protein Science,” (1999) Freeman
An extreme example is an enzymatic reaction that is diffusion limited. It’s a very fast reaction. Diffusion limited enzyme - Wikipedia
